channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl, fun again!
item.description: If you happen to be in Paris and have some time tonight, this sounds like a fun program.

item.title: GSoC - Update and Flyers
item.description: Participating in the GSoC became a tradition at The Perl Foundation. Mark Keating provides some updates for this year and calls for students and mentors to start signing up.

item.title: YAPC::Asia Tokyo 2012
item.description: It's still more than half a year from now but the next YAPC::Asia and some of the star speakers has been announced.

item.title: New stable release of perl-Verilog-Perl
item.description: I hardly know anything about Verilog and Perl but it would be really nice to see some more articles on how Perl is used with Verilog.

item.title: Many CHI caches, one configuration
item.description: Jonathan Swartz shows an example how they handle the configuration of caching for over 200 modules and Mason components.

item.title: Blinded By Our Own Experiences
item.description: How many names do you have? How should a web site store your name? What about other 'problems' and application need to handle? Basically chromatic says that the world is more complex than our assumptions and then he provides 3 ways to try top bridge that gap. The first one is 'experience'. While he does not say this explicitly I think what he might mean there is code reuse and CPAN. Surely some on has already burnt lots of hours and solved part of the problem you are dealing with. Use that solution and improve if necessary.

item.title: Fold cases properly
item.description: brian d foy explains way more than I ever wanted to know about lower and upper case. OTOH if you deal a lot with many different language you might need to understand this.

item.title: Admin tip, install modules using cpanm
item.description: Especially useful for WebGUI administrators but the same idea can be taken elsewhere to install dependencies.

item.title: Minutes of TWiki Jerusalem Release Meeting, 2012-03-02
perlfind - perldoc on steroids
item.description: This wheel has been reinvented so many times already, but for some reason none of them became widely accepted. I'd really like to see this take off as it can make our life a lot easier. This one is from Ovid.

item.title: perlfind, a more knowledgeable perldoc
item.description: This is another solution to the same problem. I already saw this earlier and now I wonder if either of these will become a de-facto standard or if they will provide two alternate but not much used solution for a problem that is IMHO especially important for beginners. This solution is from Marcel Grunauer.

item.title: Patches^W Unit Tests Welcome
item.description: LeoNerd (aka Paul Evans) has a very good point. Getting unit tests to a code base is very, very useful in the open source community. Maybe even more useful than getting patches to fix the code. They are probably the best way to express what your expectation is from a piece of code.

item.title: A contact sheet for your website
item.description: Generat a sitemap. Fetch all the pages and create screenshots. Generate thumbnails of each screenshot. Generate a single page of the thumbnails. Now you can see all the pages of your site at a glance.

item.title: Asynchronous HTTP Requests in Perl Using AnyEvent
item.description: Phil Windley writes how you can do node.js-style programming in Perl using the AnyEvent module. This is a very detailed and clear explanation of AnyEvent using a simple example.

item.title: Perl Oasis 2012
item.description: A report by garu (Breno G. de Oliveira) on his trip to Orlando.

item.title: How many faces do you count?
item.description: Max Maischein (Corion) keeps working on Image::CCV that can process images, recognize faces (and sometimes other things as faces) and provide you with the coordinates.

item.title: All of my conference presentations on slideshare.net
item.description: Perrin Harkins shared most of his slides with us.

item.title: Rakudo Star 2012.02 out – and the focus for 2012.03
item.description: Just two days apart both Rakudo and Niecza had a relase.

item.title: Current State of Exceptions in Rakudo and Perl 6
item.description: Moritz Lenz updates us about his grant work on exceptions for Perl 6. This time he shows an example how the backtrace became a lot clearer with recent changes.

item.title: mySQL Date Bug: 'date' >= '2012-03-01 00:00:00' is not the same as 'date' >= '2012-3-01 00:00:00'
item.description: Do you like mySQL? Sebastian Willing shares this issue with you.

item.title: Interpreted Languages: PHP, Perl, Python, Ruby (Sheet One)
item.description: I am not sure how old is this but it is an interesting table to use when learning one of the other dynamic languages. Even if it is not perfect.

item.title: Larry Wall Announcing a program to make life easier!!!
item.description: This link was posted by Andy Lester on @perlbuzz. This is from 1984 when Larry Wall announced the creation of patch.

item.title: How to remove, copy or rename a file with Perl
item.description: Showing 3 functions for dealing with files in Perl with the PHP, Ruby and Python counterparts.

item.title: TODO March 2012
item.description: I do montly reports on my work and make my monthly plans public. You can also see some statistics about the number of Perl Weekly subscribers on the various channels.

item.title: DC-Baltimore Perl workshop
item.description: April 14, 2012, Catonsville, MD, USA

item.title: Dutch Perl Workshop
item.description: April 14, 2012, The Hague, The Netherlands

item.title: YAPC::NA
item.description: June 13-15, 2012, Madison, Wisconsin, USA

item.title: YAPC::EU 2012
item.description: August 20-22, 2012, Frankfurt, Germany
